data.title: silent film
data.meta_description: SILENT FILM meaning: a film without any sound. Learn more.
data.text:
noun [ C ]

UK uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˌsaɪ.lənt ˈfɪlm/ us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˌsaɪ.lənt ˈfɪlm/ (US silent movie)

(Definition of silent film from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of silent film

silent film

The originals were just absolutely great, especially those in the silent film era.

There were also silent film versions made in 1910 and 1925.

The blue-tinted look of that silent film is beautiful!

There was also a 1925 silent film version of the tale.

It is the first time the critics have given its top award to a silent film.

I would have some sound of it if it weren't a silent film.

As early as silent film, directors attempted to create widescreen images.

But he took her to task -- even though it was a silent film.

It's like watching a silent film of the world.

At the beginning we imagined the images as an archive, but later we started to think of them as a silent film, like poetry.

The documentary will be followed by a screening of the 60-minute silent film.

It's an almost silent film starring one of the most recognizable actors in the world.

For a silent film it had an unbelievably urgent sense of passion, drama and agony.

Long after 1915, the silent film continued to find audiences.

I thought she had a great face -- not just physically beautiful, which she is, but a haunted quality almost, like a silent film actress.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.

in Spanish

in Portuguese
